Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2007 08:46PM Patrish wrote: I actually lost mine in the pool one day while swimming laps.  as I came into the shallow end, I saw something floating in the pool...and, whoops!  thankfully, I found it before anyone else did!  P.
Posts.Title: Boy was my face Red! yellowrose Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 04:25PM Patrish wrote: I admit that I wasn't wearing a pocketed top when I lost my form in the pool...I didn't even know it was gone. I am glad it floated, but as there were children in the pool at the time, I narrowly escaped major embarrassment...I can just picture a tot holding it up..."What's this, Mommy?...Catch!"  whew!  p.
Posts.Title: Boy was my face Red! yellowrose Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2007 01:43AM - edited Dec 12, 2007 01:45AM by Patrish hang in there, girl, only one chemo to go!  I think nearly everyone feels depressed and hopeless at some point on this rocky road--for me, it was right after I finished treatment.  all the chemo drugs can really whack you out, and mess up your system...including your brain chemicals.  maybe an anti-depressant would help?  better living thru chemistry, I say!  I had 5+ nodes and my onc has told me I am at high risk of recurrence, but I am NED and plan to see my children grow up.  let's get old together!  Pat ps, please consider your onc a paid consultant, get your port out if you want. I did.
Posts.Title: scared roxy42 Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2007 08:44PM Patrish wrote: I tried to argue with my onc that finding mets early might be beneficial with the new treatments. she told me that finding them earlier, does not necessarily mean treating them earlier. she said there are only so many treatments, and they wouldn't even start to use them unless the cancer was growing. they want to use them when they really need them, at least that is her take on things. I let her do tumor marker tests, but I don't ask for the results. I tell her to let me know when I need to panic. best, Pat
